test_questions.text: In the article from the Economist on estimating consumer surpluses, what technique was used to assign value to leisure time spent on the web?
test_questions.explanation: The technique discussed involves assigning a value to the leisure time spent on the web, reflecting consumer surplus.

test_questions.text: This technique relates to which other economic concept that you learned about in the first 3 weeks of this module?
test_questions.explanation: The technique relates to opportunity cost, as it considers the value of time spent online over other activities.

test_questions.text: How might you critique the method of measuring consumer surplus by valuing internet leisure time?
options: It assumes everyone values their leisure time equally.
It considers individual variations in leisure value.
It provides an objective measure of consumer surplus.
test_questions.explanation: The critique is that the method assumes all consumers value their time on the internet equally, ignoring individual preferences.

test_questions.text: In the market for milk, if incomes increase, and milk is an inferior good, in which direction will the demand curve shift?
test_questions.explanation: For inferior goods, an increase in income shifts the demand curve to the left as consumers buy less.

test_questions.text: What's the opportunity cost of going to the opera if tickets cost CHF 70 and you could earn CHF 50 working?
test_questions.explanation: The opportunity cost is the CHF 50 you forego by not working.

test_questions.text: If a good has a price elasticity of demand of 0.5, what does this indicate?
test_questions.explanation: A price elasticity of 0.5 indicates that demand is inelastic, meaning quantity demanded changes less than the price change.

test_questions.text: What is the opportunity cost of a farmer reducing wheat farming from 50 to 40 hectares to increase potato farming by 10 hectares?
test_questions.explanation: The opportunity cost is the output of the 10 hectares of wheat no longer produced.

test_questions.text: Offering a 50% discount to students on tickets is an example of what economic concept?
test_questions.explanation: Price discrimination involves charging different prices to different groups for the same product.

test_questions.text: What is the result of imposing a binding price ceiling on commercial rental properties at $12 per square foot?
options: No impact, ceiling is too low
More landlords convert to commercial spaces
Landlords invest more in commercial properties
test_questions.explanation: A binding price ceiling can lead to landlords converting properties to apartments due to reduced profitability in commercial rentals.

test_questions.text: In the article from the Economist on estimating consumer surpluses, what technique was used to assign value to leisure time spent on the web?
test_questions.explanation: Time valuation was used to estimate the value of leisure time spent on the internet by considering how consumers valued their time on the internet over other activities.

test_questions.text: This technique relates to which other economic concept that you learned about in the first 3 weeks of this module?
test_questions.explanation: Opportunity cost is the concept that compares the value of time spent on the internet to alternative activities, suggesting that consumers value their internet time more.

test_questions.text: How might you critique the method of measuring consumer surplus by valuing internet leisure time?
options: It assumes everyone values their leisure time equally.
It does not account for internet costs.
It overestimates the time spent online.
test_questions.explanation: This method assumes uniform valuation of leisure time among all consumers, which can lead to subjective estimations.
